papers.abstract: Identifying and prioritizing disease-related proteins is an important scientific problem to develop proper treatments. Network science has become an important discipline to prioritize such proteins. Multiple sclerosis, an autoimmune disease for which there is still no cure, is characterized by a damaging process called demyelination. Demyelination is the destruction of myelin, a structure facilitating fast transmission of neuron impulses, and oligodendrocytes, the cells producing myelin, by immune cells. Identifying the proteins that have special features on the network formed by the proteins of oligodendrocyte and immune cells can reveal useful information about the disease. We investigated the most significant protein pairs that we define as bridges among the proteins providing the interaction between the two cells in demyelination, in the networks formed by the oligodendrocyte and each type of two immune cells (i.e. macrophage and T-cell) using network analysis techniques and integer programming. The reason we investigated these specialized hubs was that a problem related to these proteins might impose a bigger damage in the system. We showed that 61%-100% of the proteins our model detected, depending on parameterization, have already been associated with multiple sclerosis. We further observed the mRNA expression levels of several proteins we prioritized significantly decreased in human peripheral blood mononuclear cells of multiple sclerosis patients. We therefore present a model, BriFin, which can be used for analyzing processes where interactions of two cell types play an important role.

events.Text: Identifying and prioritizing disease-related proteins is an important scientific problem to develop proper treatments. Network science has become an important discipline to prioritize such proteins. Multiple sclerosis, an autoimmune disease for which there is still no cure, is characterized by a damaging process called demyelination. Demyelination is the destruction of myelin, a structure facilitating fast transmission of neuron impulses, and oligodendrocytes, the cells producing myelin, by immune cells. Identifying the proteins that have special features on the network formed by the proteins of oligodendrocyte and immune cells can reveal useful information about the disease.

Secondary Object: networks formed by proteins of oligodendrocyte and immune cells

Context: Importance of prioritizing disease-related proteins for effective treatments and emergence of network science as a critical field in prioritization
Purpose: Prioritize disease-related proteins for better treatment development
Method: utilize network science to build interaction graphs and conduct computational analyses
Analysis: Despite recognizing immune cell involvement, precise mechanisms remain elusive
Challenge: Insufficient understanding of underlying mechanisms despite available data
Implications: Potential advancements in treatment strategies for complex diseases like MS

events.Text: We investigated the most significant protein pairs that we define as bridges among the proteins providing the interaction between the two cells in demyelination, in the networks formed by the oligodendrocyte and each type of two immune cells (i.e. macrophage and T-cell) using network analysis techniques and integer programming. The reason we investigated these specialized hubs was that a problem related to these proteins might impose a bigger damage in the system.

Primary Object: most significant protein pairs that we define as bridges among the proteins providing the interaction between the two cells in demyelination
Secondary Object: networks formed by the oligodendrocyte and each type of two immune cells (i.e. macrophage and T-cell)

Context: A problem related to these proteins might impose a bigger damage in the system
Purpose: To investigate the role of these protein pairs in bridging interactions between oligodendrocytes and immune cells in demyelination processes
Method: Using network analysis techniques and integer programming
Challenge: Analyzing such intricate molecular pathways presents challenges due to the high complexity and numerous variables involved

events.Text: We showed that 61%-100% of the proteins our model detected, depending on parameterization, have already been associated with multiple sclerosis. We further observed the mRNA expression levels of several proteins we prioritized significantly decreased in human peripheral blood mononuclear cells of multiple sclerosis patients. We therefore present a model, BriFin, which can be used for analyzing processes where interactions of two cell types play an important role.

Primary Object: that 61%-100% of the proteins our model detected, depending on parameterization, have already been associated with multiple sclerosis

Purpose: Demonstrate the effectiveness of the model in detecting known MS proteins and observe reduced mRNA levels of prioritized proteins in MS patients
Analysis: Understanding why these proteins exhibit altered expression patterns helps explain the model's ability to distinguish between healthy and pathological states in MS patients
Implications: Identifying such patterns may open up new avenues for diagnosing and treating multiple sclerosis through molecular profiling

papers.abstract: The alevin-fry ecosystem provides a robust and growing suite of programs for single-cell data processing. However, as new single-cell technologies are introduced, as the community continues to adjust best practices for data processing, and as the alevin-fry ecosystem itself expands and grows, it is becoming increasingly important to manage the complexity of alevin-fry's single-cell preprocessing workflows while retaining the performance and flexibility that make these tools enticing. We introduce simpleaf, a program that simplifies the processing of single-cell data using tools from the alevin-fry ecosystem, and adds new functionality and capabilities, while retaining the flexibility and performance of the underlying tools.

events.Text: The alevin-fry ecosystem provides a robust and growing suite of programs for single-cell data processing. However, as new single-cell technologies are introduced, as the community continues to adjust best practices for data processing, and as the alevin-fry ecosystem itself expands and grows, it is becoming increasingly important to manage the complexity of alevin-fry's single-cell preprocessing workflows while retaining the performance and flexibility that make these tools enticing.

We introduce simpleaf, a program that simplifies the processing of single-cell data using tools from the alevin-fry ecosystem, and adds new functionality and capabilities, while retaining the flexibility and performance of the underlying tools.

Context: enhancing single-cell data processing efficiency within computational biology due to the availability of alevin-fry tools
Implications: Integration of additional functionalities suggests enhanced processing efficiency across various studies in computational biology
